I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the annual country programming mission in December 2010, the Government of 
the People’s Republic of China (PRC) asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide 
policy and advisory technical assistance (TA) for a study to support sustainable urban transport 
in Beijing. A fact-finding mission visited Beijing in July 2011 and reached agreement with the 
executing  agency  on  the  impact,  output,  implementation  arrangements,  cost,  financing 
arrangement, and terms of reference for consulting services. The TA is in the ADB’s technical 
assistance  program  for  the  PRC  for  2011.  The  design  and  monitoring  framework  is  in 
Appendix 1. 
 
2.  Beijing, the capital of the PRC, had 19.6 million residents in 2010 and an urbanization 
rate of 98.8%. One of the most economically advanced cities in the PRC, Beijing symbolizes the 
country’s rapid economic growth and serves as a model of urban development. Its transport 
policy  influences  other  large  cities  in  the  PRC.  The  magnitude  of  its  transport-related 
problems—and the implications for other large cities and for global climate change—is also 
attracting considerable international attention.  
 
3.  Rapid urbanization and motorization, combined with high population density, have led to 
serious congestion and air quality problems in Beijing. A recent study by IBM found that Beijing 
and Mexico City were the world’s worst cities for traffic jams, with scores of 99 out of 100 in the 
“commuter pain index.” While Beijing accounts for less than 2% of the PRC’s population, it has 
more than 10% of its vehicles.1 Per capita motor vehicle registration has surpassed the level of 
many leading cities in the world (1.8 times the level in Paris, 2.3 times that in New York). The 
number of registered vehicles grew from 1 million in 1997 to 4.7 million in 2010, an average 
annual rate of 12.8%, and the number of vehicles is expected to double by 2015. 
 
4.  The adverse effect of congestion is estimated to cost the equivalent of 7.5%–15% of 
Beijing’s  gross  domestic  product.  Congestion  and  air  pollution  costs  contribute  the  most, 
although climate change and accident costs are also substantial. Research has shown that 
more than three quarters of the air pollution in Beijing comes from vehicle carbon monoxide and 
hydrocarbon emissions.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
5.  Travel  demand.  The  increase  in  travel  demand  plays  a  leading  role  in  producing 
congestion both on the roads and in public transport in Beijing. As the population grows and 
incomes rise, people need or desire access to numerous social and economic activities, leading 
to  an  increase  in  travel  demand.  As  the  urban  environment  becomes  more  complex  and 
sprawled, average trip lengths also increase. 
 
6.  Infrastructure supply. During the past decade, the fourth, fifth, and sixth ring roads 
were built in Beijing. These have become the backbone of Beijing’s road network. However, the 
expansion of ring roads could not cope with the increasing and induced passenger car travel 
demand, and the ring roads have become congested during peak hours as vehicles pour into 
the central business district. The solution—to mitigate congestion by providing new roadway 
capacity—has created a vicious cycle in which new capacity soon leads to renewed congestion 
and a travel pattern that depends more on passenger cars. 
 
7.  Car ownership and dependency. Growth in Beijing’s population, combined with rising 
personal incomes, has resulted in increasing car usage and ownership. From 2003 to 2009, the

modal share of passenger cars increased from 27.7% to 34.0%. Limitations in land use planning 
and inadequate public transport and nonmotorized transport have resulted in frequent and short 
personal vehicle trips (2.64 trips per day in 2005, with 44% less than 5 kilometers), and rising 
private vehicle usage. The average annual driving distance per vehicle is 16,000 kilometers, 
which is slightly higher than in Los Angeles, 1.5 times higher than in London, and 2.4 times 
higher than in Tokyo. Because of the high vehicle traffic volume in Beijing, private cars no 
longer offer efficient mobility around the city, and the scope for finding additional space for more 
road infrastructure is ever diminishing.  
 
8.  Public transport operation. Public transport can play a vital role in the management of 
congestion.  In  Beijing,  however,  public  transport  is  less  attractive  because  of  its  poor 
performance, limited capacity, lack of network coverage and reliability, and discomfort and 
inconvenience for passengers. Although the demand for public transportation is significant, the 
current public transportation system has limited capacity and is unable to increase its market 
share.  The  lack  of  advanced  public  transport  systems,  such  as  bus  rapid  transit,  has 
exacerbated the situation. By 2009, the modal share of public transport in the central business 
district was only 39%, which is much lower than in other leading cities (86% in Paris, 92% in 
New York). 
 
9.  In December 2010, the Beijing municipal government (BMG) announced 28 new travel 
demand management measures to reduce traffic congestion and vehicle emissions. These 
focus on (i) introducing quantitative restrictions on vehicle ownership and peak-hour usage, 
(ii) providing  more  parking  spaces  and  park-and-ride  facilities,  and  (iii)  prioritizing  public 
transport and road construction to address bottlenecks.2 
 
10.  Many  of  these  recent  measures  focus  on  producing  early  or  temporary  relief  from 
congestion. More comprehensive and long-term approaches are also urgently needed. These 
may include congestion charging, optimizing the usage of existing infrastructure, providing good 
quality public transport to accommodate passengers diverted from private vehicle use, and 
adopting travel demand management (TDM) measures. In August 2011, Deutsche Gesellschaft 
für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) and the Beijing Transport Research Center (BTRC) 
launched a TA project entitled Transport Demand Management in Beijing—Emission Reduction 
in Transport. BTRC is the think tank of the Beijing Municipal Committee of Transportation, which 
is responsible for transport policy in the capital. The BTRC conducts studies on urban transport 
development strategy, policy, and planning in Beijing. The TA will conduct a detailed study to 
identify at least three TDM measures for potential implementation in Beijing, and quantify the 
reduction of greenhouse gas emissions that they could bring about. 
 
11.  Previous initiatives, studies, and data collection activities to address urban transport and 
traffic management in Beijing have not been sufficiently coordinated and comprehensive to 
generate  integrated  solutions.  The  potential  short-  and  long-term  strategies  need  to  be 
evaluated  on  a  common  basis  to  determine  and  compare  their  likely  effectiveness.  This 
                                                 
2  The measures include (i) restricting vehicle ownership by rationing new registrations using lotteries (the 2011 quota 
of 240,000 new registrations is a third of the 2010 level) and placing a 5-year moratorium on the acquisition of new 
government vehicles (in Beijing there are 700 government vehicles, about 15% of the city’s total fleet); (ii) giving 
priority to public transport and high occupancy vehicles by designating special lanes, building passenger transport 
hubs, and encouraging the use of school buses and company shuttle buses; (iii) restricting vehicle usage through 
the use of number-plate-based traffic controls on congested roads during rush hour, and by the government using 
modern technology such as teleconferencing to reduce travel demand; (iv) parking pricing measures and parking 
space provision, including categorizing the city into three zones according to the traffic congestion level, and 
providing an additional 50,000 parking spaces in downtown Beijing, 200,000 in other areas, and 30,000 at subway 
stations located outside the fourth ring road; and (v) road construction, including new tunnels in the eastern and 
western sections of the second ring road, and 37 kilometers of fast lanes and 200  kilometers of new roads in 
downtown Beijing.

3
evaluation needs to consider a range of sustainability evaluation indicators such as emissions, 
health costs, and the quality of services in addition to the congestion index (which relies solely 
on road speeds). The aim is to determine the individual measures and combinations that could 
provide the basis for an effective integrated urban transport management policy and strategy for 
Beijing. 
 
12.  The TA is intended to support the BMG in finding suitable and sustainable solutions to its 
urban transport problems. In so doing, the TA will directly support the emerging urban transport 
priorities  of  the  PRC’s  Twelfth  Five-Year  Plan,  2011–2015  and  ADB’s  country  partnership 
strategy.3 It is also aligned with the pillars of ADB’s Strategy 2020,4 focusing on inclusive and 
environmentally  sustainable  growth.  The  TA  addresses  one  of  the  focus  areas  of  ADB’s 
Sustainable Transport Initiative Operational Plan.5 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The impact of the TA will be that an energy efficient, environment friendly and intelligent 
urban transport system is developed in Beijing. This will be demonstrated by the announcement 
of the policy and strategies by the BMG, the start of planning and implementation, and the 
introduction of sustainability indicators in the decision-making process for urban transport in 
Beijing. The outcome of the TA will be the submission of recommendations for sustainable 
urban transport policy and travel demand and traffic management strategies to the BMG.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
14.  To  achieve  the  impact  and  outcome,  the  TA  will  (i)  produce  recommendations  for 
sustainable urban transport policy and traffic management strategies in Beijing, (ii) establish a 
Beijing urban transport policy and strategy evaluation model, and (iii) publish a knowledge 
product on sustainable urban transport strategy for Beijing.  
 
15.  The TA will be conducted in three phases. In the first phase, previous studies and data 
will be reviewed, an inventory of urban transport strategies to be evaluated will be prepared, and 
a detailed study approach and methodology will be designed including criteria for evaluating the 
expected performance of the strategies. In the second phase, the existing Beijing transport 
model will be prepared for use by the TA, additional surveys and data collection will be designed 
and conducted, and the model and data will be used to evaluate the expected performance of 
the strategy options for addressing Beijing’s urban transport needs. In the third phase, the TA 
will prepare case studies to elaborate on preferred strategy options, strategy recommendations 
for consideration by decision makers, and a knowledge product for publication. 
 
16.  The Beijing Academy of Social Science (BASS) will provide the existing Beijing transport 
policy data and the BTRC will make the Beijing transport model available. The model will be 
updated by incorporating an additional module to simulate vehicle emissions and convert from 
peak-hour and nonpeak-hour time periods to an hour-by-hour time-dependent model. It will be 
calibrated to test various policies and strategies. In addition to estimating speeds (the main 
indicator  currently  used),  the  model  will  measure  sustainability  indicators  such  as  energy 
consumption, emissions, and health costs.

17.  Three main types of strategy options will be examined: (i) TDM strategies including 
(a) past strategies such as restricting vehicle ownership and usage, and parking pricing; and 
(b) potential new strategies such as charging schemes including congestion pricing, fuel pricing, 
distance-based pricing, and fee and rebate schemes; (ii) infrastructure improvement strategies, 
based on a review of Beijing’s transport infrastructure development plans and identification of 
strategy options with potential to contribute to a more sustainable balance between private 
vehicles, public transport, and nonmotorized transport, including metro development and bus 
priority  lanes;  and  (iii)  traffic  operation  improvement  strategies,  based  on  a  study  of  the 
relationship between Beijing’s road network structure and traffic congestion, and identification of 
promising improvement options such as on-ramp and off-ramp metering during peak hours. 
 
18.  For strategies that require further data, survey and analysis, or modeling, an overall 
survey plan, proposed modeling approaches, and analysis methodologies will be prepared. For 
TDM  strategies,  target  groups  will  be  identified  either  as  institutions  or  individuals,  and  a 
revealed preference and/or stated preference survey will be conducted. The survey will be 
designed to identify the status of existing TDM measures, the level of participation by the users, 
and the requirements for further promotion of TDM measures. For infrastructure improvement 
strategies, road and public transport inventory data will be obtained from the Beijing transport 
model,  and  performance  data  will  be  obtained  from  the  BTRC.  For  traffic  operational 
improvement  strategies,  traffic  performance  data  compiled  in  the  Transportation  Model 
Department (TMD) of the BTRC will be analyzed to identify the recurrent bottlenecks and a site 
survey will be carried out to identify the operational problems for selected locations. 
 
19.  Workshops will be held toward the end of each of the three phases to consult with a 
wide  range  of  stakeholders,  partners,  and  external  experts.  The  first  and  second  phase 
workshops will be used to review and consolidate work produced and to agree on work plans for 
subsequent phases. The third phase workshop will consider the findings of the TA and decide 
on the recommendations to propose to the BMG. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
20.  The TA is estimated to cost $450,000 equivalent, which will be financed on a grant basis 
by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-other  sources).  The  Government  will 
provide counterpart staff, office space with utilities and telecommunication access, materials, 
data, and documents. 
 
21.  Additional funding is expected to be available on a grant basis from the $1.9 million 
allocation of the Climate Change Fund approved by the Climate Change Steering Committee on 
16 March 2011 for Promoting Sustainable Low Carbon Transport in Asia and the Pacific. The 
government will provide counterpart staff, office space with utilities and telecommunication 
access, materials, data, and documents, and other services to finance the total costs such as 
cost  of  utilities  for  the  consultants,  counterpart  professional  staff,  and  support  staff.  (See 
Appendix 2 for details of the cost estimates and financing plan.) 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
22.  BASS,  a  research  institute  under  the  leadership  of  the  Beijing  Communist  Party 
Committee and the municipality, will be the executing agency for the TA. BASS conducts 
research on economics, politics, culture, social coordinated development, and the long-term 
strategic planning of the capital. The TA will be implemented over 18 months from March 2012 
to June 2013.

5
23.  A steering committee will be established to facilitate the TA activities. Its main tasks will 
be acquisition of necessary data from the government and its agencies, and consultations 
between stakeholders. BASS, the government, and the BTRC will be the main participants on 
the  steering  committee;  other  necessary  agencies  will  be  identified  and  included  on  the 
committee during the TA. A coordination committee will also be formed to consolidate the 
activities such as workshops and liaison between ADB and GIZ. The coordination committee will 
comprise  steering  committee  representatives,  ADB,  and  GIZ.  The  steering  committee  and 
coordination committee will work in parallel to ensure full support and assistance from the 
government and relevant agencies, and to maximize the cooperation between ADB and GIZ. 
 
24.  The BTRC has agreed to collaborate with the TA. Its TMD will provide access to the 
Beijing transport model and traffic data. ADB and GIZ will promote close collaboration and 
information sharing between the two TA projects to maximize synergies and avoid duplication. 
 
25.  The  TA  will  require  8  person-months  of  international  consulting  services  and 
14.5 person-months  of  national  consulting  services  to  carry  out  the  terms  of  reference 
(Appendix 3). Individuals and firms will need to be recruited. Individual consultants are needed 
because the TA is an advanced assignment that requires highly specialized expertise in TDM, 
transport pricing policy, transport emission analysis, transport and traffic analysis modeling, and 
network analysis. The firm will be recruited on the basis of the quality of the proposal (90%) and 
cost of services to be provided (10%) using simplified technical proposal procedures. The 90:10 
weighting is appropriate because of the high level of expertise required by the TA. 
 
26.  Coordination of different consultants with different expertise will be important for the 
success of the TA project. The project leader will be an experienced urban transport specialist 
with extensive experience in urban transport, environment, and TDM. The project leader will be 
responsible for coordinating the consulting activities and consolidating the outputs produced by 
different parts of the consulting team. 
 
27.  BASS will provide a suitably furnished office with utilities and telecommunication access, 
materials, data, and documents required by the TA project. BASS will also cover the cost of 
utilities for the consultants, counterpart professional staff, and support staff. TA equipment will 
be procured by the consultants and transferred to BASS upon completion of the TA. The TMD 
of the BTRC will provide the consulting team with access to the Beijing transport model updated 
in 2011 and traffic data compiled since 2007. An emissions module for the model will be 
procured and calibrated by the consultants, and transferred to TMD upon completion of the TA. 
 
28.  The consultants will be required to submit an inception report, interim report, draft final 
report, and other progress reports stated in Appendix 3. These reports and the performance of 
consultants will be monitored and evaluated by BASS and ADB. Three workshops with a range 
of stakeholders, partners, and external experts will be held to review and disseminate the TA 
findings. The final report will be published on the ADB website. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
29.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $450,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for the Beijing Sustainable Urban Transport, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General 
1.  The proposed policy and advisory technical assistance (TA) requires a wide range of 
expertise in travel demand management (TDM) and nonmotorized transport (NMT) strategies, 
urban transport infrastructure development, traffic operation, and transport and traffic modeling 
(including  emissions  modeling  and  health  impact  modeling).  A  good  understanding  of  the 
existing urban transport and policies and measures implemented in Beijing also is needed. The 
TA requires close coordination among these experts, with the executing agency and other key 
agencies involved, and between the different phases of the TA. 
2.  The  consultants  will  perform  their  tasks  in  close  cooperation  with  relevant  local 
institutions and other participating consultants in (i) identifying items for study, (ii) acquiring and 
analyzing existing data, (iii) specifying and designing surveys, (iv) linking analysis results to 
policy and strategies, (v) preparing evaluation model input data and reviewing modeling results, 
and  (vi)  producing  final  recommendation  reports.  Three  workshops  and  initial  and  interim 
reports  will  allow  each  consultant  to  understand  other  components  of  the  TA  and  the 
relationship between components. 
3.  Urban transport in Beijing has been the subject of many previous studies by national and 
international experts who have produced a considerable body of literature, traffic data, and 
transport models. The consultants are responsible for reviewing the existing studies and data at 
the  initial  stage  of  the  consulting  service  and  making  effective  use  of  these  materials  in 
designing the approach to conducting the consulting services. 
4.  As  this  TA  will  cooperate  with  the  TA  provided  by  Deutsche  Gesellschaft  für 
Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ), the allocation of consultants for different specialties, the 
division of international and national consultants, and the engagement of consultants through 
firms or individually may change according to the assignment of activities between two TA 
projects. 
B.  Terms of Reference 
5.  The  TA  requires  22.5  person-months  of  consulting  services  (8  person-months 
international and 14.5 person-months national) for the following five specialties over 18 months. 
1.  Project  Manager:  Urban  Transport  and  Travel  Demand  Management 
Specialists (3 person-months international with more than 20 years experience; 
6 person-months national with more than 10 years experience) 
 
6.  The consultants will lead the TA consulting team. The consultants will have extensive 
experience in TDM, public transport, NMT, vehicle emission, road network analysis, and traffic 
operational management. The project manager is responsible for supervising and coordinating 
the  work  of  all  international  and  national  specialists,  and  producing  consolidated 
recommendation reports. The project manager is also responsible for the TDM part of the 
project. 
 
7.  The main tasks of the consultants include conducting an analysis of the level of service 
of the public transport system and NMT, and suggesting improvements. The Transport Model 
Department of the Beijing Transportation Research Center Public will provide transport card 
data for the analysis. An NMT study will be carried out for areas selected in consultation with the

(x)  Participate in the workshops and seminars as a resource person and produce 
workshop reports and knowledge products and services (KPS) materials. 
(xi)  Produce  final  TDM  strategy  recommendations  and  consult  with  the  Beijing 
municipal government (BMG). 
 
2.  Transport  Fiscal  and  Pricing  Strategy  Specialists  (1  person-month 
international with more than 10 years experience; 1 person-month national with 
more than 10 years experience) 
 
8.  The consultants are responsible for reviewing existing fiscal and pricing measures in 
Beijing and best practices around the world, and providing recommendations for Beijing. The 
impact of the measures on emissions and travel demand will be included in the consulting work. 
The impact of a recent parking fee increase in Beijing on travel demand will be reviewed to 
establish the elasticity of pricing on travel demand and congestion charging options for Beijing 
need to be studied to support BMG’s recent policy decision to introduce congestion charging. 
The  consultants  need  to  work  closely  with  the  transport  model  specialist  in  estimating 
congestion and the reduction in emissions from different congestion charging options. Fiscal 
measures  will  be  studied  in  terms  of  reducing  emissions.  International  comparison  and 
recommendations will be produced. 
 
(i)  Provide a list of transport pricing strategies (congestion pricing, parking pricing, 
and transport-related fiscal policies) for achieving sustainable transport from best 
practice examples around the world, and assess their applicability to Beijing. 
(ii)  Review the existing transport pricing strategies applied in Beijing, produce an 
effectiveness appraisal of those strategies and opportunities, and generate a 
pricing strategy road map. 
(iii)  Plan the coordinate municipal fiscal measures with national fiscal measures. 
(iv)  Design interview and stated preference survey for investigating the effectiveness 
of existing and potential transport-related pricing strategies. 
(v)  Produce  input  data  for  a  transport  model  for  evaluating  proposed  pricing 
strategies. 
(vi)  Coordinate with the TDM specialist in producing fiscal and pricing strategies. 
(vii)  Review the effectiveness evaluation results produced by the modeling specialists.

Appendix 3  11 
(viii)  Develop and implementation plan for the recommended measures. 
(ix)  Estimate the costs of the recommended measures. 
(x)  Participate in the workshops and seminars as a resource person and produce 
workshop reports and KPS materials. 
(xi)  Produce strategy recommendations and consult with BMG. 
 
3.  Vehicle Emissions Specialists (1 person-month international with more than 
10 years  experience;  1  person-month  national  with  more  than  10  years 
experience) 
 
9.  The task of vehicle emission specialists is to estimate vehicle emissions based on the 
current  vehicle  inventory  and  traffic  flow,  and  develop  a  methodology  for  estimating  the 
economic impact of emissions on health. The existing vehicle emission factor data and hourly 
traffic flow and speed data will be provided to the consultants. The consultants will also be 
responsible  for  providing  future  vehicle  emission  factors  based  on  the  emission  standard 
change and the introduction of low- or zero-emission vehicles. The consultants will also review 
emission estimates produced by the emission module of the transport modeling for different 
improvement measures. 
 
(i)  Review existing vehicle emission standards and emission factor data in Beijing. 
(ii)  Identify the necessity of updating emission factor data. 
(iii)  Design a survey for vehicle emission factor. 
(iv)  Review methodologies for measuring the impact of vehicle emissions on health 
and recommend the best methodology for Beijing. 
(v)  Design a survey for measuring the impact of vehicle emissions on health. 
(vi)  Produce input data for transport and traffic model for evaluating emissions. 
(vii)  Participate in the workshops and seminars as a resource person and produce 
workshop reports. 
(viii)  Produce TDM strategy recommendations and consult with BMG. 
 
4.  Transport Planning and Network Modeling Specialists (2.0 person-months 
international with more than 10 years experience and 4.5 person-months national 
with more than 10 years experience) 
 
10.  The main tasks of the consultants are to enhance existing Beijing VISUM transport 
model1 in order to estimate the network performances and emission reductions by the different 
measures generated by other consultants. The consultants will also perform network analysis 
on the effectiveness of the ring-road system and future road plans. The consultants will also 
estimate  scenario-based  impacts  of  future  infrastructure  provisions  for  roads  and  public 
transport on congestion and emissions. The consultants will work closely with the Transport 
Model Department of the Beijing Transportation Research Center and will have an advanced 
level of understanding of the software used for the Beijing transport model and emissions 
module. 
 
(i)  Review the existing Beijing transport planning model specifications for road and 
public  transport,  and  produce  model  update  requirements  for  evaluating  the 
strategies generated by consultants. 
(ii)  Produce survey requirements for the model update. 
                                                 
1  VISUM is derived from the German language term “Verkehr In Städten Simulationsmodell” meaning Traffic In 
Cities Simulation Model.

12  Appendix 3 
(iii)  Review the quality of model responsiveness to different strategies and further 
calibrate the model and the incorporated emission module to the existing model. 
(iv)  Evaluate the existing road and public transport infrastructure supply policy and 
evaluate planned road and public transport infrastructure plans.  
(v)  Evaluate existing ring road system in terms of mobility and accessibility, and 
produce balanced supply policy for the road sector. 
(vi)  Design site survey requirements and perform a site survey 
(vii)  Produce input data for the transport model for evaluating network effectiveness 
of the ring road system. 
(viii)  Develop the implementation plan for the recommended measures. 
(ix)  Estimate costs of the recommended measures. 
(x)  Participate in the workshops and seminars as a resource person and produce 
workshop reports and KPS materials. 
 
5.  Traffic  Management  and  Traffic  Modeling  Specialists  (1  person-month 
international with more than 15 years experience; 2 person-months national with 
more than 10 years experience) 
 
11.  The main tasks of the consultants are to identify locations in Beijing with recurrent 
congestion, the causes of the congestion by analyzing traffic volume, the speed and path data 
in  Transport  Model  Department  of  Beijing  Transportation  Research  Center;  and  provide 
operational and  physical  improvement  measures.  The  consultants will  perform  microscopic 
analysis to provide the estimated effectiveness of the improvement measures.  
 
(i)  Identify locations with recurrent congestion during morning peak and evening 
peak hours using probe car data archived in Beijing since 2007. 
(ii)  Review existing Beijing traffic analysis model specifications and produce model 
update  requirements  for  evaluating  traffic  management  and  operational 
improvement strategies. 
(iii)  Review  the  quality  of  model  responsiveness  to  different  traffic  management 
strategies and perform further calibration of the model. 
(iv)  Design the site survey requirements for the selected locations with recurrent 
congestion and perform a site survey. 
(v)  Produce  traffic  management  and  operational  improvement  measures  for  the 
selected locations and evaluate the results. 
(vi)  Produce a network data update for the transport planning model. 
(vii)  Develop the implementation plan for the recommended measures. 
(viii)  Produce estimate costs of the recommended measures. 
(ix)  Participate in the workshops and seminars as a resource person and produce 
workshop reports and KPS materials. 
 
C.  Reporting Requirements 
12.  The consultants will produce the following reports for the executing agency, BMG, BTRC, 
and the Asian Development Bank (ADB): (i) an inception report 2 weeks after the first workshop; 
(ii) the first interim report 4 weeks after the first phase of the TA; (iii) a second interim report 
4 months after the second workshop; (iv) a draft final report after the third workshop; and (v) a 
final report after receiving comments from the executing agency, BMG, BTRC, and ADB and 
other consultants. All reports will be written in English and translated into Chinese. Four hard 
copies and two soft copies of all the reports and workshop presentation materials will be 
submitted to the executing agency.
